channel.title: Comments on: How to structure your NodeJS Models

item.title: By: Bleh
item.dc:creator: Bleh
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/how-to-structure-your-nodejs-models-2/#comment-23">Bleh</a>.
nevermind, i see it is a static method on the User function/"namespace", and the rest are instance methods on the user objects. JS is weird man.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Bleh.

nevermind, i see it is a static method on the User function/”namespace”, and the rest are instance methods on the user objects. JS is weird man.

item.title: By: Anders Borg
item.dc:creator: Anders Borg
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/how-to-structure-your-nodejs-models-2/#comment-23">Bleh</a>.
What I think he means is that the user class should not have a method for getting a list of all users. A method that would return "IDs of all users this user is related to (somehow)" makes sense though. There could be a users class with user as a sub-class though.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Bleh.

What I think he means is that the user class should not have a method for getting a list of all users. A method that would return “IDs of all users this user is related to (somehow)” makes sense though. There could be a users class with user as a sub-class though.

item.title: By: Bleh
item.dc:creator: Bleh
item.description:
You say that "But you donâ€™t want the method for fetching users to be part of each user because that doesnâ€™t make any sense", however it seems to me that it is still part of every user object? or am i missing something?
Thanks for the article, im new to nodejs and this defs helped to get me going with my models :)
item.content:encoded:
You say that “But you donâ€™t want the method for fetching users to be part of each user because that doesnâ€™t make any sense”, however it seems to me that it is still part of every user object? or am i missing something?

Thanks for the article, im new to nodejs and this defs helped to get me going with my models ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: Francis Tito
item.dc:creator: Francis Tito
item.description: how can i structure my model and route using normal mysql command like select from database ,i did but i think my queries does not pass through the model becouse there some condition i provide in the model for a particular field but when i text add user may be even if am not fall those condition still it function and add user as well
item.content:encoded: how can i structure my model and route using normal mysql command like select from database ,i did but i think my queries does not pass through the model becouse there some condition i provide in the model for a particular field but when i text add user may be even if am not fall those condition still it function and add user as well

item.title: By: Saul Luz
item.dc:creator: Saul Luz
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/how-to-structure-your-nodejs-models-2/#comment-19">Anders Borg</a>.
I'm new on nodejs, not js. This article seems to me good. About your question: look for mongoose. []'s ... After a better search I think you alright: http://mongoosejs.com/docs/api.html#model-js
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Anders Borg.

I’m new on nodejs, not js. This article seems to me good. About your question: look for mongoose. []’s
…
After a better search I think you alright: http://mongoosejs.com/docs/api.html#model-js

item.title: By: Chanlito
item.dc:creator: Chanlito
item.description: How to structure your NodeJS Models? according to this article it's more like "How to structure your NodeJS Models Terribly."
item.content:encoded: How to structure your NodeJS Models? according to this article it’s more like “How to structure your NodeJS Models Terribly.”

item.title: By: Anders Borg
item.dc:creator: Anders Borg
item.description: I was with you until I saw the stringify. Do you mean you are storing the whole user profile as JSON in one database cell? Can you effectively search for individual values later? I'm not using JS on the server side yet, so this looked odd to me.
item.content:encoded: I was with you until I saw the stringify. Do you mean you are storing the whole user profile as JSON in one database cell? Can you effectively search for individual values later? I’m not using JS on the server side yet, so this looked odd to me.
